intro: Selago longipedicellata, commonly known as the long-stemmed selago, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive bracts and often edible roots. The plant is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, clustered flowers that bloom in late spring. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a reddish tinge, contributing to its ornamental appeal. Selago longipedicellata is typically found in moist, sandy soils along streambanks and in open woodlands.
